entry.title: Combined summary - Small update to BIP 62
entry.summary: In various discussions among Bitcoin Core developers, several topics were addressed. Firstly, Pieter Wuille proposed changes to BIP 62, his anti-malleability proposal, making two of the seven new rules mandatory for old-style transactions in new blocks. The reason for this change was to drop the requirement for signature verification engines to be bug-for-bug compatible with OpenSSL and instead require strict DER compliance for signatures. Secondly, there was discussion about how to mitigate the issue of new signatures by the sender, but no specific solution was agreed upon. Thirdly, Gregory Maxwell and Aaron Voisine discussed the security of DSA nonces and the difficulty of proving a particular nonce generation scheme is being used without revealing the private key. They noted that some signature systems are naturally randomness-free, such as most hash-based signatures and pairing short signatures, but not DSA or any of its derivatives. Additionally, an author questioned the rationale behind rule #4 in Bitcoin transactions and expressed a preference for backwards compatibility. Lastly, Pieter Wuille investigated the number of non-DER signatures that make it into blocks and found none in the last 11 blocks and 389 blocks, respectively.Several conversations and discussions have taken place among Bitcoin Core developers regarding various aspects of the Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) 62. The proposal aims to prevent transaction malleability, with rule #4 being particularly significant as it prevents unauthorized modifications to scriptSig, which contains non-push operations that can modify the signature and change the transaction ID. To ensure security, Pieter Wuille has sent a pull request to make two of the seven new rules mandatory, even for old-style transactions. However, there are concerns about backwards compatibility, and Wuille suggests investigating how many non-DER signatures still make it into blocks before making any changes.There have also been conversations about DSA nonce properties and the suggestion of requiring all signatures deterministically generate k per RFC6979 to mitigate the issue. However, this was met with a response of "nope" as there is no reasonable way to prove a particular nonce generation scheme is being used without revealing the private key. It is difficult to control how a DSA nonce was generated in the verifier in a way that would prevent equivalent but not identical signatures. Other discussions center around the lack of specificity in rule #4, with Gregory Maxwell raising concerns about different interpretations of what constitutes a "push operation." Wuille acknowledged the issue and agreed to write an update to address it, as well as expanding the rules to include 6, and reordering the rules so that those applicable to all transactions come first. There were also discussions about extra consensus rules and how they cannot prevent someone from creating outputs whose spending transactions will be malleable. Overall, these conversations and proposed changes aim to ensure the security and functionality of Bitcoin transactions and address potential vulnerabilities or issues.The Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) 324 has been released, which aims to enhance the security of Bitcoin transactions. BIP 324 proposes a way for wallet software to support a new type of Bitcoin transaction called "Pay to Contract," which uses a multisignature (multisig) script that includes a commitment to a contract. This allows users to include additional rules in their transactions, beyond the standard consensus rules enforced by the Bitcoin network.The proposal also introduces a new opcode called OP_CHECKTEMPLATEVERIFY, which allows for more complex scripts to be included in Pay to Contract transactions. However, it's important to note that no mandatory rules were changed in this revision, making it purely a clarification and reorganization of the text.The authors of BIP 324 hope that its implementation will lead to the development of new use cases for Bitcoin, such as smart contracts and decentralized finance (DeFi) applications. But they also acknowledge the limitations of extra consensus rules and emphasize the importance of properly testing any new features before deploying them on the main Bitcoin network.Overall, BIP 324 represents an important step towards improving the security and functionality of Bitcoin transactions, while maintaining the integrity of the underlying network. Its release is a testament to the ongoing efforts of the Bitcoin community to innovate and evolve this groundbreaking technology.
